SENT.plain: OBJECTIVE: To gain further understanding of the antiphospholipid syndrome(APS)
METHODS: Analysing clinical and laboratory data on ten cases of APS
RESULTS: Thrombocytopenia appeared in all cases
Venous thrombi of limbs appeared in five cases and neurological abnormalities in two cases
Renal impairments were found in three cases
One case manifested left renal venous thrombi and the other two cases thrombotic microangiopathy
Budd-Chiari syndrome was found in one case

One of the ten cases was catastrophic APS (CAPS) presented as acute diffuse swelling, cyanosis, pain, ischemia and necrosis in fingers and limbs, recurrent shock, ascites, hepatic and respiratory dysfunction
Anticoagulants and corticosteroids could be effective for dealing with APS
It was critical to treat catastrophic APS with anticoagulants or plasmapheresis as early as possible
CONCLUSIONS: APS shows variable manifestations for good prognosis, but catastrophic APS has fatal risk
The main treatment for APS is the use of anticoagulants and immunosuppressives
